This may be an off-the-wall suggestion but you could try, just for kicks,
approaching the OCR problem a little differently.  You could look at one row
or column as an input vector and step the network through cycles looking at
consecutive columns/rows.  Of course, this implies a greater network
complexity, but it's a different approach if you're trying to cut down on
inputs...may be interesting anyhoo.

Now someone else can say why this is a crazy idea :)

Best,

jeff

On Fri, 09 Sep 2005 23:08:00 -0000, Carl Strange wrote
> I kicked around a few ideas for a project, many getting wildly out of
> hand, and settled on Braille character recognition.  It let me play
> with a bit of development while using your OCR experiment as a
> framework.  I thought the reduced 7 X 5 input grid and very distinct
> character set would be a snap for the network.  Now I know better. 
> Thirty-five inputs and twenty-six outputs is too much for a one-to-
> one connected net so the problem isn't trivial.  I'm having fun playing
> with the various search parameters, especially the frequency of "add
> connections" and "add nodes".
> 
> The downside of adding an experiment is my SharpNEAT library and some
> of the Form1 initialization differ from the standard release.
> 
> Lots to play with and I haven't even looked at the network code.
> 
> Carl
